The Ontario Lakes Project: Ahmic Lake

19 Oct 2011

Ahmic Lake’s is a swimmer’s lake. And the most famous swimmer to emerge from those waters was a brainy, beautiful and eccentric distance swimmer named Marty Sinn.

Marty learned her chops at Camp Ak-O-Mak–a girls only competitive sports camp on Ahmik Lake. Ak-O-Mak’s unofficial camp motto was “Lady, if you want your daughter to sew beads on a belt, send her somewhere else.” And Marty wasn’t your average ‘lady.’
A 1964 edition of Sports Illustrated  pointed out Sinn’s eccentricity: “At Ak-O-Mak she is forever wandering about like Hamlet with her nose in a book. Two days before the race she was lounging on the sun deck with a copy of Mad magazine and a well-chewed paperback edition of The Brothers Karamazov.”
In fact, Marty went on to say:
“I’m suspicious of people who are terribly gung-ho about all phases of athletics—diet, sleep. I eat chocolate ice cream before a race, blueberry pancakes and chocolate cake…I’m a little critical of people who train so intensely—they become machines instead of people, they become masochists. I just don’t believe in it. It’s detrimental to your character later, naturally, and to the sport, too. Obsessions can become vicious. You get so wrapped up, you lose perspective. I think parties are important, for instance. Sometimes I won’t have anything to drink, but sometimes I really get in the bag.”
Parties didn’t stop Marty from finishing second in the 24K CNE Lake Ontario Swim in 1963 and from being the first woman to complete the 36K “Around the Island Swim” in Atlantic city in 1964.
Camp Ak-O-Mak is still alive and well on Ahmic Lake. Together with its boy’s camp (also on Ahmic) it has trained over 60 men and women to be Olympians.
